In "Contributions of the Sexologists," Lillian Faderman catalogs the sexologists' explanations for the "phenomena" of lesbianism and homosexual love in general at the turn of the century. Faderman especially highlights the works of Richard von Krafft-Ebing and Havelock Ellis, sexologists of the late 19th century who theorized that lesbianism is a result of "cerebral anomalies," relating it to violence, homicide, and suicide. They labeled lesbianism "inversion," that is, an inversion of emotions and everything a "normal woman" should be. At the time Krafft-Ebing and Ellis were studying lesbianism, women were just beginning to enter the workplace and fjord independent lives for themselves, when for so long they'd been nothing but submissive accessories to man's needs. Romantic friendship had not only been tolerated up to that point, but also encouraged. However, now that economic independence was beginning to be possible for women, this feminine solidarity was seen as a threat to patriarchal society--if women could work, and didn't NEED men or marriage--if they eventually became independent, who knew what could happen? The threat was growing, and so sexologists like Ellis cast a morbid light upon romantic friendship and cases of lesbianism which were arising. Calling these women abnormal and even insane, Ellis separated lesbians from society by diagnosing them with neuropathic degeneration, and went so far as to exclude them from the realms of the female sex. He created a third sex to fit the "inverted" women. Ironically, women embraced Krafft-Ebing's and Ellis's exclusion, finally having a sufficient excuse to break away from the hearth and marriage--which up until then had been their curse. If they had a disease, a cerebral disorder, they had an excuse to exclude themselves and live apart from "normal" life for women of that time. They formed entire communities of "inverted" women, celebrating their abnormalities and acquiring life-long partnerships with other like-minded women. They became successful in careers and lived long, happy, unmarried lives. However, the world took little notice and merely marveled at these women as if they were somehow deformed--medical studies ensued and novels dramatized the "abnormalities" which were suddenly out in the open. Radclyffe Hall illustrates the life of one such abnormal woman. Miss Ogilvy has, for as long as she can remember, not fit in with her feminine counterparts. As a child she'd rather have lifted weights and played football with boys than play dolls with her sisters, she longed to join the business world and enjoy the abounding opportunities that were men's, yet she had always been confined to a life of the mundane. When war was declared, Miss Ogilvy felt the primal urge to ship out with the soldiers and fight on the front lines, where it was most dangerous. Yet she was a woman, and her gene configuration prevented her from pursuing this dream. She found a way, however, to be there on the front lines, digging the wounded out of the trenches and risking her life. While in the thick of the war, Miss Ogilvy nearly forgot her sex and the cursed life of submission which she was forced to endure. But it all ended too soon, and Miss Ogilvy was sent back to England to live a quiet, dull life with her loathsome sisters. Time passed and Miss Ogilvy grew older and more irksome, and increasingly worried that she was whiling away the precious last moments of her life so unhappily. So, on a whim, Miss Ogilvy sails out to a tiny, remote island upon which the only civilization is one hotel, owned by the same person who owns the entire island. This woman shows Miss Ogilvy the ancient remains of a warrior killed in battle, and Miss Ogilvy reacts in a most uncharacteristically emotional manner. That night she has a dream in which she is a tribal man, thousands of years prior to the present-day Miss Ogilvy, on the island. She is strong, robust, and uninhibited. Spending an evening with a young tribal woman, Miss Ogilvy is overcome with an immense satisfaction and peace. Miss Ogilvy dies happy, and is found dead sitting at the mouth of the cave in the morning. Her dream was a manifestation of who Miss Ogilvy longs to be, her deepest desires of what she wishes her life could have been. Miss Ogilvy is a representation of the "inverted" woman--longing for a life that was not yet socially accepted (and hardly is today) at the time she was alive. Her life was a sad testament to the inequalities these women were forced to endure, and the fact that they were made to feel tainted and unnatural simply because their lifestyle threatened the heirarchy of patriarchal society. well, i do believe i'll go on this retreat. so i won't be around this weekend. so there's this huge ass storm moving through milwaukee right now...severe thunderstorm warning, tornado watch, etc. i shouldn't be surprised--it's been hot and really windy all day. but god...from the 23 floor, it's fucking incredible. exhilirating, but fucking scary. we had the windows open, and it felt like there was a tornado...the posters on the walls were rattling so loudly you had to shout to be heard. doors were slamming shut of their own accord from the wind--all our shit was flying off our desks and shelves all around the room. the wind was screaming--literally, screaming--through the windows. just standing there, my hair was flying all around me like medusa, and i had to hold on to something heavy so i wouldn't be blown over. it took two people pulling with all our might to close the window. we could see people below outside on bikes and being blown off course...riding in crooked or zigzagged lines. haha. the sky looked fucking ominous...dark and swirly and angry looking. i actually saw lightning touch down not far from campus. trees were tossing about madly, and erin saw a huge tree branch fly past our window. lol. fucking crazy. before i left to go down to dinner (i figured if there was a tornado, i'd be safer on the 3rd floor rather than the 23rd, hehe) i secured all my shit just to be safe. it was freaky. seems to have died down a bit now, but that could just be because i'm only on the 3rd floor. i swear, there's nothing like expiriencing a severe thunderstorm from the 23rd floor with big bay windows. sweet. :D p.s. this song is perfect for the weather.

the car last night so we could save time in the morning and not have to wake up early (my move in time was set for 12:30, which meant we'd have to leave by about 11:30). the packing passed with little incident, except when mom broked down and started crying. but i hugged her and she calmed down and it was fine. we fit everything in nicely and were very organized, and in the end we were pretty me to take my levothyroxin (i have to take it at the same time each day on an empty stomach, and mornings an hour before breakfast is the easiest time). i got up, freezing and groggy, took my meds, TV (with dvd), a mini-fridge, and there's another dresser-storage thingy, and the third desk. now, they accomodated the bed part of our rooms for four people, but nothing else. we only have three more. i took the bottom bunk and half the opposite dresser-storage thing. damn, apparently they're closing this up at 8...in 4 minutes. i thought it was open till 12 am (that's what the door says). oh my incision is healing nicely. it's itchy as hell, but it looks much better, and the range of motion in my neck is increasing daily. i'm feeling more and more like a normal person each day. however, i'm still incredibly tired, i'm still tingling quite a lot, my neck is still very sore, and i still have occasional bouts of nausea. my appetite's not quite back, but it's coming. yesterday i had bloodwork done, and today dr. marden called with the results. whaddya know? my calcium level's back down to 7.6. fucking sweet. so things are complicated. mom is talked about me moving in to my dorm on monday, but then coming home and not staying overnight, because i may need to go back to uw-hospital. this really is not good, i have to say. it's really bad that we had to cut surgery so close to moving in. i can't even believe it--i'm moving in in a day and a half. i'm nowhere near being mentally prepared. i can't even grasp the concept. i'm not enjoying being in this position, and i've been in relatively low spirits. i don't really know what it is...last night i was overcome with a very depressive sort of emotion that i can't pinpoint. i was lonely and exhausted and depressed. my thoughts are racing. i suppose this is the aftermath of surgery and the beginning of a huge transition, but i'm just so tired. it's hard to deal with everything right now when all i want to do is give my body adequate time to heal and recover. this is really no fun at all. i really have no idea what's going to happen. since it's a weekend, i won't know till monday morning, which is cutting it as close as you possibly can, since i'm moving out at 11 am. fucking ridiculous. i suppose worst-case scenario would be hypo-calcium and hypo-thyroid for the rest of my life and would need to be on calcium and thyroid supplements for the rest of my life. sounds like a grand old time. *sigh* i suppose i'll go lay down. again.

so, where i left off, i'd just been wheeled into my personal hospital room. throughout the rest of the night my memories are still splotchy...mom said i wasn't quite pulled out of the anesthetics yet so i slept a lot on and off. when i really woke up for the first time, i asked mom how the surgery had gone. she said that when doctor mack talked to her, he told her the surgery went well, that it took a little longer than expected (about 3 hours), and that it was a very bloody surgery because of all the blood vessels connected with the thyroid. hehe. he said that the thyroid weight about 110 grams--about equivalent to a stick of butter. haha. unfortunately, i believe dr. mack & co. kept the thyroid for study purposes, so i don't think i'll be pickling it and feeding it to anyone. sorry. could've made a nice stew.

anyways, i was on darvoset, which i've been told is the strongest narcotic available. narcotics, as i've said, do not do good things to katie. i was unbelievable nauseated. they asked me to try to eat some jello, said maybe i just needed something in my stomach. i tried, got about a teaspoon in and wanted to vomit more than ever. i was terrified of throwing up, though (i couldn't even move my neck--i had a mental image of my incision ripping open with the force of vomitting), and concentrated every fiber of my being into keeping my stomach in control. the nurses gave me some anti-nausea medicine through my IV, and soon i felt slightly better. they then gave me some vicodin, among other various drugs--i really have no idea at that point of what exactly was polluting my veins. soon again i was beyond nauseated. my neck felt as if it was in a vice grip, my throat was on fire, my stomach was raging in nausea, and every square inch of my body felt like it was being stabbed repeatedly by nails--of course, when speaking of my left inner elbow, this was true. nurses were coming every hour to draw more blood, and always in the same place. over my entire hospital visit, i'd estimate that they took my blood at least 19 times--at two vials per lab, that's 38 vials of blood. i'm not exaggerating. my arm is black and blue and yellow and is still killing me, probably more than my incision. toward the end of my stay i almost cried whenever another lab specialist knocked on my door and said, "just gotta take some more blood". it was horrible. now, i'm no stranger to having blood taken--i had it taken about twice a month during the entire grave's experience. it doesn't hurt me, and it doesn't gross me out. but by the time i left the hospital, i could feel that godforsaken needle sliding in and out of my skin, could feel the blood being squeezed from my arm (thanks to my clenched fist--in the end i actually had to pump the blood out), and it hurt more than anything i can describe. the hole they were drawing blood from didn't heal for a long time--i'd have to put pressure on it continually for 5 minutes or the blood would soak through the gauze. when the lab specialists came in at night, they'd stop in, say, "just gotta take some blood," and i'd mumble, "ok," hold out my arm, and fall back asleep. ridiculous. 

but back to that first night. yeah. so, pretty much i was in more pain than i've ever experienced and wanted to die. i couldn't talk--my voice was nothing more than a hoarse whisper, so it was nearly impossible to tell the nurses of my problems. by around 2 am, my hands were crippled in a praying-mantis position, my lips and face muscles were paralyzed in tension, my leg muscles were cramped and paralyzed (charlie horse style), and my entire body was wracked with pins and needles so intense i felt as if i were on fire. not to mention the nausea and pain. eventually the nurses had the resident doctor come in (dr. mack was still in surgery), and he recognized a severe defficiency of calcium. checked my labs and said, yes, my calcium was at about a 7.0, when it should have been at an 8.7-10.0, or something. mom asked him what that meant, he explained that my parathyroid glands had been disturbed during surgery, and because of their hyper-sensitivity, they were screwing with my calcium levels majorly. turns out that the parathyroids were under the impression that i was severely osteoporosised and they were draining every ounce of calcium from my blood and into my bones. he flicked lightly at the facial nerve in my face, and apparently my lips and eyes twitched. it's a test they do when this happens to people, i guess, but it's extremely rare for the test to work--i guess it's just kind of obscure for a doctor to see. so the doctor was all excited, and had his training-doctor team (who'd observed my surgery) come and look. i guess he'd never seen it before. haha. so that was all fine and good, but i was still pretty crippled, pretty naucious, and pretty in pain. mom asked him what potentially could happen if this calcium got any more out of control...i was out of it, like i said, and i heard him say a lot of things, but among them i heard the word "seizure." at that point i freaked out a bit. i'd just come out of major surgery, my insides were on fire, everything was dark and flashing at me, i had needles in my arms, my neck felt like it'd been partially severed, i could't move, my entire body was on fire with tingling, i was practically paralyzed, and i was locked in a little sterile cell in some unknown building surrounded by people i'd never seen before in my life who were giving me god-knows-what in god-knows-what quantity through a tube in my hand. things were terrifying, and i had a flash-back to my dystonic reaction to compazine. it was horrible. i think i was moaning, "owie, owie, owie, owie..." and sobbing. the nurses did the best they could, hooked me up to an ECG which i had to sleep with (yeah...they basically just took my top off and started sticking these pads all over my chest...so i was naked to the waist for all the world to see...i swear, every ounce of privacy deserts you in a hospital). eventually the narcotics did one thing right and i was asleep. it was very, very bad.

i was awoken a little while later, considerably more calm, by dr. mack popping his smiling face into the room. if i haven't mentioned it before, dr. mack is a very dumbledore-esque personality. which immediately put me at ease. he told me that during surgery one of the four parathyroids was embedded in my thyroid, so dr. mack had to remove it and put it in some muscle. that's why i was experiencing such extreme hypo-calium reactions. he said that it was the most common reaction to thyroid surgery, and that i shouldn't worry, that i was being cared for and they wouldn't let me go until they were sure i was fine. considerably less troubled, i fell asleep when he left.

i woke up the next day pretty early--around 5 am to be exact--and couldn't think what to do with myself. i was feeling better--still in pain, but my neck muscles felt worst because of the awkward position in which i had to hold my head and sleep. i stood up and went to the bathroom by myself. it was only a few steps to the bathroom, but still, this was a big accomplishment, because it was the first time i'd even stood up since surgery. i then washed my face as best i could (which wasn't very good), and laid back down. i couldn't fall asleep, and it was boring as hell. nurses popped in very often to take blood or give me tums (calcium supplements--three of them every 2 hours) or some other medication (i was only on motrin by then--the narcotics were doing bad things), and a young female doctor-in-training (who was apparently assigned to me) stopped in every so often to ask questions. also the resident doc and his team of training doctors stopped in often. not great fun. mom woke up with a migraine a few hours later and puked her brains out. i felt helpless and worn out and tired of the hospital. after mom puked she felt better, so when the nurses suggested we go on a walk, we accepted and went down to the surgical waiting area to get on the internet for a while. that was an odd experience...i put on another hospital gown so my butt wouldn't show, and i put on underwear and footies, but i was still hooked to this IV tree, hadn't showered, had dried blood in my hair, and had to walk in a stooped over position and take 3-inch long steps. i felt about 85 years old amongst a sea of normal, healthy people. haha. we then walked back upstairs to my room, and i dozed for a while more. the same things happened all day--nurses upon nurses doing different things to me, doctors coming in to tell me my calcium wasn't changing and that i'd need to stay another night at least, and blood being continuously drawn. i whiled away the hours watching the abhorred television and eating my first meal--ice cream, cranberry juice, and mashed potatos. hehe. i couldn't finish it all, but i didn't feel nauseated, so that was good. later on in the day, dr. mack came in, told me what everyone else had told me, made sure i was comfortable (he resituated my pillows, hehe), and got me more ice cream to push the calcium. aww. he was doing a nurse's job. it was really sweet--i definitely felt well cared for, at least. he told me i would in fact be staying another day. he told the nurse to hippo my IV, or something like that, and one of the nurses came in and started fiddling with it. before i knew what was happening, she'd disconnected the tube and blood was spurting from my hand like a river, covering my hand in blood and soaking my bedsheets. i stared horrified at my hand while she cheerily closed the IV back up, leaving the needle in my arm with the blue clip on the end and a short tube, but she taped down the tubing and didn't attach it to the IV bags. it was the most disgusting thing ever. mom and i decided to go for another walk, and went back to the computers for a while, then out onto the courtyard. it was much warmer than i'd expected it to be, but windy. we strolled around for a while more, then went back to my room and ordered food and watched more TV. heidi and justin & ann called later on, and that brightened my spirits. after a long, tiring while, later that night, mom and i fell asleep.

my sleep was punctured by visits from lab people, my arm growing increasingly more sore, but i slept in disjointed fragments until about 8 am, when i awoke with a start to see dr. mack smiling serenely at me from the foot of my bed, his hands behind his back. haha. it was funny. i said, "oh, hi!" but he put his finger to his lips and said, "shh!" and pointed to mom, who was still asleep. teehee. he told me that my calcium levels were upand we'd continue pumping the calcium and taking blood, and see how things went that day. i said ok, and he left the room. lol. i fell back asleep and woke up at around 11 again. mom woke up, and we ordered some breakfast and watched tv. the nurse came in and asked me if i wanted to shower. i quickly agreed--i hadn't showered since sunday night and felt really gross. the nurse supplied me with a number of towels and some shampoo, conditioner, and soap. she instructed me to keep the water from running directly on the incision (though it was ok to get it wet, just no soaking), and to pat dry when i was done. 

i took a long shower, washing myself very gingerly, and keeping my back to the shower head. i was dizzy and had to sit down (luckily there was a little seat in the shower), but all in all it was a success and i felt much cleaner afterward. i put on regular clothes, thankfully, had mom french braid my hair, and lay back down on the bed, quite exhausted and a bit nauseated. around 2 pm the nurse came in and they said my calcium levels were up to about 8.4 and i'd be able to leave. dr. mack came a little later and confirmed this, shook my hand and said goodbye, and set up an appointment to see me again september 8. a guy from pharmaceuticals came in and gave me the rundown on the meds i'd be on: levothyroxin, the thyroid supplement, tums, for calcium, motrin, for pain, propranalol, because i'd been on it for a long time and needed to be weaned off of it, and calcitrol, for vitamin D and calcium. eventually i'd only be on levothyroxin, but the rest i needed for various reasons for a while. 

so, around 3 pm or so, i was discharged. mom gathered our belongings and headed down to get the car and bring it around while a nurse situated me in a wheel chair and zoomed me out of the hospital and down to the entrance. she helped me sit on a bench to let me wait for mom and said goodbye. after waiting a while, i saw mom walking towards me. she said, "guess what? we have a flat tire." incredulous, i followed her back into the hospital and waited while she talked to security and called gmac. i got a wheelchair and she pushed me along with her to a patient services office, where they let her make long distance calls without charging. she made so many phone calls it was ridiculous. eventually, after about an hour, she'd made arrangements for her friend mrs. backhaus to deposit enough money into her account to pay for a new tire, for a tow truck to come to the hospital and tow it to a farm and fleet in madison, and for my friend ben to come pick us up. everything in place, mom and i went outside to wait. we waited for over an hour, and finally the tow truck showed up. mom drove the car reluctantly out of the garage and over to the truck (she had to drive on the rim because the clearance for the parking garage was too high for the truck), where the guy put the car on the ramp. soon after, ben showed up. we drove to farm & fleet and waited while the tire was changed--apparently a tiny nail was the cause of the flat. it's incredible, because mom hadn't moved the car since parking it in that very spot monday morning. so ridiculous. we repaired the tired and finally drove home. i was so exhausted. when i got home zillions of people called, and i talked for a short while, ate a little bit, and crashed. i was so incredibly tired, but it felt good to sleep on a normal bed. 

so concluded my long, arduous, hospital stay. some of the details may be jumbled--i'm still not clear on everything--but that's the jist of it. it was tough, but it's over. i think.

okay. i read through my missed friends pages finally, so whether i commented or not, i definitely read your journals. so, feel loved. hehe. again, thanks so much, everyone, for all the support and good wishes i've received since monday. so, this is probably going to be a ridiculously idealistic attempt of mine, but i am henceforth going to try to post in chronological order the mixed memories and scattered mental notes i jotted down in my brain over the course of this surgical experience of mine. i'll probably end up doing this in installments depending what my health allows, because i want to be as detailed as possible and record everything i remember. but i'll just get down to it. please excuse the less than par rhetoric, typos, and scattered trains of thought...i'm kinda dizzy. my official preparation for surgery began a week before surgery. it wasn't really "preparation"--all i had to do was abstain from alcohol, ibuprofen, aspirin, and blood-thinning drugs. tylenol was ok. so, that part wasn't tough. the friday before surgery (remember, it was scheduled for a monday), the RN who would be assissting my operation, called mom in the morning while i was still asleep. she went over the dos and don'ts, among which were--1)no eating after 12 am sunday night/monday morning, 2)eat a peanut butter & jelly sandwhich before midnight sunday night as the last thing in my stomach for protein, 3)shower the night before with a special surgical soap called hibiclens that they'd given me at my pre-op visit, scrubbing the incision site for two minutes, then repeating the process, and 4)surgery was scheduled for 7:30 am, but i'd have to be at the hospital at 5:30 am. eek! the last bit of news came as somewhat of a shock, since surgery had originally been scheduled for 11 am, but mom and i decided to deal with it, and leave the house at 4:30 am. the weekend flew by, and before i knew it it was sunday. mom and i woke up early and spent the day cleaning--a lot--so we could wear ourselves out and fall asleep early enough to get a full night's rest before waking up before dawn. kaitlyn stopped by to wish me luck before surgery. it was really sweet. i was very glad to see her. mom and i ate dinner, then began to pack our stuff up (preparing, mind you, for one overnight stay in the hospital). mom packed some food in an insulated tote for overnight because we couldn't afford to buy any. beth arrived later that evening to drop off a coffee for me from berres brothers and a few vintage national geographics she'd found at a rummage sale that she thought i'd enjoy (totally sweet--they're from the '60s!) and wish me luck for surgery. again, very sweet of her. after a brief bout of panic in which neither mom nor i could locate her wallet and mom began to freak out (i finally found it under a seat in the car), i ate my pb&j and showered. the soap was liquid and red. hehe. foreshadowing? i like to think so. after getting out of the shower, i double-checked that everything was in place, french-braided my hair, and hit the hay. it took forever for me to fall asleep, and when i finally did, i think i only dozed lightly. i felt like i'd just gotten into bed when the alarm went off at 4 am and i sat bolt upright, awake despite my lack of sleep. mom said she hadn't slept at all. we got dressed. i lovingly stroked my incision free (though bulging) neck which for the last time in my life would contain a thyroid (though, admittedly, diseased). i wish now that i'd enjoyed the freedom of a full range of motion in my neck a little bit more, but i digress. at 4:30 mom and i stepped into night (i felt like a bandit) and drove off toward madison, stopping first for gas. i was completely relaxed, exited, and aware of my surroundings. i was making furious mental notes already, wanting to remember the experience when all was said and done. i remember gazing up into the pre-dawn sky and seeing only one little star (or planet) flickering feebly in the west, but accompanying us faithfully all the way to madison. we made our destination before the sun had risen above the horizon. drove into the parking garage and found that the third space was unoccupied--one upside of having monday morning surgery scheduled. entered the hospital entrance of uw-hospital and made our way to the "D" section and up to floor 6, then checked in. before i could fully prepare myself, mom was guided to a waiting area and i was whisked away to a room where i was provided with a hospital gown (how i grew to hate that thing), a robe, footies, and a hat, and was told to take off every ounce of clothing/jewelry/shoes and store them in some plastic bags which were provided. i was then told to wait in the room until people came in. after staring at the blank wall for a half an hour, listening to the sounds of my neighboring victims before the slaughter, i shuffled feebly out to the nurse's desk and asked if i could give my glasses to my mom (she had my glasses case). the nurse gave me the okay, and i went into the surgical waiting area, feeling beyond moronic in my surgical garb among normal looking people. hehe. i gave mom my glasses and retrieved my book so i could do something while waiting for something to happen. i went back to my room and reclined uncomfortably on the bed i would also grow to hate within the next few days. i read until one of the nurses came in to ask me questions, make me sign forms, fill out a survey, talk to me about the surgery and sign some more forms. then she allowed mom to come in. soon i was visited by anesthesia--a nice woman who complimented me on my hair and shoved a needle into the top of my right hand without wincing. she didn't hook me up to an IV tree yet, though. following her visit, a male nurse (a relatively good looking one, at that--sort of reminded me in an abstract way of heidi's friend curt) came in and introduced himself, told me he'd be assissting in the surgery, and asked if dr. mack had stopped by. i told him he hadn't, and he said that after dr. mack came in they'd wheel me out. after the nurse came the female anesthesiologist again and her assisstant, who (as she put it) would be the one i could thank since he'd be giving me the drugs. hehe. he was very funny and i felt quite relaxed. finally dr. mack came in, bright and cheery and looking very endearing in his scrubs, hat, and mask, and began quipping in his german accent, smiling, and laughing. he remarked on my calm appearance and assured mom that i would be perfectly fine. at 7 am the male nurse came back, along with the two anesthesiologists, and told me it was time. my palms sweating slightly, i hugged mom (she was more nervous than i, i could tell), laid back on the bed and attempted to relax as the team wheeled me out into the brightness and publicity of the hall outside. i was wheeled into a veritable sea of people, all in either white smocks or scrubs, all looking at me calculatingly. it didn't occur to me until after the surgery that they'd all be either assissting in or observing my surgery. in fact, i realized later, that my surgery had been video taped and would be used as a case study (i'd signed papers to give my consent to this). i felt like a bug under a microscope, but still wasn't wholly nervous. i was wheeled into a room, followed by my medical posse, where i was finally hooked up to the IV. i think they must have started me off on something milder, probably vallium, because i can remember only dimly the next few minutes. i remember them hooking up my IV, taking my vitals, transferring me to the operating table, and being asked to breathe into a plastic mask that was placed on my face. but the very last thing i remember was the feeling of that mask on my face, because i was unconscious within seconds. now, when i had oral surgery, i was completely unconscious, but i still have one very vague memory from the midst of the surgery. i remembering hearing a faint voice floating across my unconscious, a voice which said gently, "okay, now just open your mouth a little bit wider." a vision of white scrubs, a bright light, and surgeons hovering overhead flickered into view as i effortlessly opened my mouth wider, and as the same voice said soothingly, "gooooood." haha. very "lucy in the sky with diamonds". but that's all i remember. with this surgery, i remember nothing. over the span of the 3 1/2 hours it took in surgery, i have nothing but a blank space in my memory. the next very very dim and vague memory i have is of lying in my hospital bed, unable to move, oxygen tubes in my nose, a large quantity of gauze and bandages on my neck, a blood pressure cuff on my arm which inflated and deflated regularly at 10-minute intervals, an ECG monitor strapped heavily onto my chest, a pulse clip on my finger, an IV hooked up to my arm, elastic stockings encasing my legs, and huge calf-length blood pressure cuffs encasing my legs, deflating and inflating continuously in patterns to keep the blood flowing in my legs. i felt as if i were in a full-body cast--and i may well have been, for i had no desire to move and probably couldn't have if i'd wanted to. i faded in and out of consciousness, catching vague glimpses of my surroundings before falling out of consciousness again. a faceless motherly nurse hovered gently over me, feeding me ice chips in my dehydration and attending to my various other needs. she seemed to me an angel...she kept me comfortable and soothed me in my vague confusion, always hovering overhead, watching me, and treating my beaten body with incredible gentleness and care. i wanted to thank her, but my throat was completely enclosed and when i tried to make a sound, nothing escaped my mouth but air. she seemed to understand, however, and continued in her care. as i began to gain more consciousness, i became aware of my surroundings faintly. i was in a huge, white room which was lined with beds and recovering patients like myself, all of which were being hovered over and attended to by hordes of nurses like mine. i think my head was in some sort of encasement, because i could barely move it a centimeter, but my peripheral vision saw a man lying next to me, conscious, his leg in a large cast, being fed ice chips by a nurse. the room was about half the size of a gym, and lined with patients like me. must have been at least 15 of us. i got the vague impression that i and my recovering neighbors were fetal infants, completely helpless in the hands of our angelic nurses. i kind of felt the way l'engle describes meg's experiences at the hands of aunt beast in the end of "a wrinkle in time". haha. it was probably the most peculiar sensation i've ever experienced. i was trying to describe it to justin later on the phone, and the analogy he equated it to was that i and the other recovering patients were victims of war in a war hospital. haha. that's also another good analogy--perfectly representative. again, very very very weird experience. obviously, if you haven't gathered, i was in the recovery room--where patients go when they're recovering from surgery. it turns out that i was in there for another 3 1/2 hours--most of which i was unconscious. the reason for the length of my time in there was apparently because the hospital was overloaded and they needed to wait for patients to leave before i could get into my room. i didn't mind, obviously...all my needs were being attended to. i think there must have been a cathetor in me, as well, because i never needed to go to the bathroom. it was like a worry-free dream. i had absolutely nothing to worry about. definitely love it. finally, after 7 hours, a room was freed up and i was wheeled up to my room and finally saw mom. i went into my room, and i think i must have slept some more, because i don't remember much until it was later and darker. ok, well, i'm beginning to get really woozy, so i'm going to get off. i'll continue my account tomorrow. :)

neck and multiple stitches. i'm not going to go into details now, but i just wanted to let you all know that i'll be here for at least one more night because of complications due to my parathyroid glands (they regulate calcium). heidi called this morning and i told her a bit more, so if you really want to know, talk to her. otherwise i should be home on wednesday sometime, but i can't make any promises. but i'm ok, no worries. i went into surgery around 8 am. it took about 4 hours i believe. dr. mack said it was very bloody. hehe. he also said that my thyroid weight 110 grams (normal is about 30 grams). haha. the reason i'm having complications is because there are four tiny parathyroid glands that surround the thyroid, and if they're even bumped they can go out of whack--they're hugely sensitive. one of my parathyroid glands was embedded in my thyroid, so dr. mack had to remove it and embed it in my neck muscle. the other three are fine, but it'll take a while to get this fourth one regulated. until then i'm hypo-calcium, so they're feeding calcium to me through an IV and tums. i'm getting blood drawn every two hours. last night, as a result of this low-calcium stuff, i was hugely naucious, and my hands, legs, arms, chin, neck cheeks, and lips were numb and tingly. also, when some resident doctors came in late that night, they did this test by tapping on my facial nerve. apparently sometimes when a patient is hypo-calcium their eyes and mouth twitch when the nerve is tapped, and mine did. the doctor was really surprised and excited at seeing this, apparently because it's really rare and he nor anyone else he knew had ever seen it. hehe. so i was their learning experience last night. also, a bunch of training doctors have been popping in every so often. it's kind of intimidating...this huge horde of grad students popping out of nowhere to talk to me when i can barely talk and am wearing nothing more than a hospital gown that opens at the back. haha. i'm not enjoying the sensation of being almost naked in a public place, that's for sure. anyways, i've been popping tums regularly, getting calcium dripped into my IV, blood taken every two hours (i i finished the stranger. good book. albert camus is the biggest cynical realist i've ever encountered--but way cool. he was a wonderful author...very influential. the only other one of his works i read was a short story, the title of which i've forgotten. anyways, it was a rather long short story that spanned the events of one night. it highlighted a man (and a few others) sentenced to be killed by a firing squad at dawn. man, it fucking blew me away. just his realism in itself is incredible. i mean, he doesn't mince words. he doesn't make things pretty or tasteful, he doesn't censor a thing. it's truly raw. the stranger was awesome as well. so honest in the beginning it was almost mundane, and so ridiculous and cynical at the end. it's a humbling sort of book. fuck, man, none of it matters. it really doesn't. do what you want, if it feels good. whatever. it's not bad. just kind of apathetic. neutral. so i have to ponder for a while more what i derived from this book. each book i read leaves me feeling a certain way, leaves me with some realizations and new ideas. they inspire me and empassionate me or depress me or anger me. it's all wonderful, no matter how it makes me feel. the fact that something holds that power is incredible, and should be appreciated. seriously, i think it's so important. reading literally broadens horizons, opens the mind, and plants new ideas. and as long as new ideas are continuously growing and evolving, people will progress. and progression fights hatred. even just reading things like harry potter is wonderful. i mean, look at it. harry potter has reached how many billions of people in how many countries? kids are turning off the tv and opening a book. that is incredible. i truly believe that reading is the best way to help people grow and learn. keep on reading, folks. anyhow, sorry, i didn't mean to turn this into a public service announcment. whenever i finish a book i'm struck by how powerful reading really is, and how it helps me and teaches me so much and makes me grow, and how i wish so many more people read regularly (not just the comic page or magazines). and how much better of a world this would be. seriously. ah, anyways. i'd really like to read a bit of an upper, now. something of inspiration, maybe. i want to read the 12th planet, but i don't think i'm in the right mindset yet. i was thinking about candide. i suppose we'll see. mom and i are on a mad last ditch effort to clean out the house and prepare for a rummage sale. today we cleaned out heidi's room (found nothing incriminating except a condom wrapper, hehe ;D), and tomorrow we plan on tackling either the basement or the attics. joy, i can't wait. both are equally gross. ah, well, such is life.

oh god. i just fnished on the road. i don't even know what to do with myself. christ. i can't even articulate what i derived from the book. i suppose that's understandable...it's such an incredibly ambiguous book i can't imagine what critics had to say about it. but i thought it was amazing. my god. i've never encountered a book that so perfectly harnessed life at its most raw. soooo incredible. so prolific, profound, and honest. it's probably the most honest thing i've ever read. so sad. so very very gravely sad. not a depressive sad, not a whiney sad, just a perfect, beautiful, incredibly truthful sadness. it eminates from the core of the book. from the core of dean. everything about the book was sad...the road, dean, every single character, sal himself, every city, the wilderness, the lifestyle, the music. whether it was a beautiful, pure sadness or a mournful, pitiful sadness, it was all there. life is sad, at its core. life is so many things, but at its purest, it's sad. don't get me wrong...i'm not saying that everything sucks and people should just sit around and cry all day. that's the opposite of what i mean. i just mean that life is so many things, life can be so many things, but the one thing that encompasses and exemplifies is all is the real, pure, raw sadness of it. it's beautiful. no wonder kerouac used the word "sad" to describe everything. it's the perfect word. the only true, honest thing i know for sure from this book is that it made me incredibly, deeply sad. dean. dean was the book, he was at the heart of everything. he was the god of the beat generation, and on the road was the bible. dean, the homeless kid who was born on the road, the hustler and con man, the nymphomaniac, the drug addict, the drunk, the man who was three times married and twice divorced, the maniac, the idiot, the young, crazy-eyed fiend of the night and the music and the road and women and kicks and life. he was so addicted to life, so completely delirious from the sheer essence of life that grows among the people and the wilderness and the road that can go anywhere, that he left humanity in the dust to pursue his own crazy kicks that fueled his life. he swallowed the earth and it radiated from him in waves like the waves of heat that radiate from the sun. people marveled at him, laughed at him, humored him, condescended him, pitied him, were delighted by him, and loved him...but they didn't--and they couldn't--understand him. no one ever could. he was like a child, amazed by everything, delighted by everyone, and could do nothing but rush around and gaze at everything incredulously, repeating, "yes! yes!" as if people were doing something incredible and profound and wonderful just by existing. and the people, in turn found him first endearing, odd, even wonderful, but they all grew annoyed at his constant incredulity and rushing and high-strung lifestyle and turned their backs on him, the angel. what they failed to understand, what they failed to try to understand that dean had a perfectly sane and ingenious grip on life and what life should be. he was delighted by people and things who were doing nothing but living, existing the best way they knew how. dean saw it, and that it was beautiful and miraculous and incredible and something that should be praised every day, every moment, and he did. he didn't stop for creature comforts, he couldn't stay locked in a house or in a steady paying job. he couldn't live such a common life and know that life was slipping him by. he wanted to cherish every breath he took and make every moment of his time wonderful and exciting, the way it should be. schedules don't matter, houses don't matter, all these trinkets and comforts and material things simply don't matter, whatsoever. life is to be attained in the raw, when material life is absent. enlightenment can only be gained when life is pure. dean pursued life with such a lustful, thirsty passion, he took no care for himself or his personal well-being. all that mattered was the pursuit of life, what others called his kicks. people who wanted nothing more than blind existence with false comforts saw dean's actions as "throwing his life away" (what they really meant was throwing his material, false life away) and caring only for himself and his kicks. they were incredibly wrong on that accusation. dean cared nothing for himself...he forgot everything, even himself, in his crazy pursuit for life. he saw everything and did his best to drink everything in, to dig life at its purest. i'm thinking especially of his trip to mexico and his kicks in san francisco and denver with the poor black jazz community. music, the purest form of expression when played by the soul, spoke to him and understood him and drove him. he idolized those who could make the music scream the blues and the craziness of life. he'd devoted his life to living, something that few know how to do. and at the end of the book, the final image of dean is prophetic. the image of him "ragged in a motheaten overcoat he brought especially for the freezing temperatures of the East, walked off alone...rounding the corner of Seventh Avenue, eyes on the street ahead, and bent to it again." shunted, however inadvertently, by his friends, penniless and friendless, unable to speak, a dejected angel of humanity mingling in the sleet and the trash and the cold, the one person to have harnessed life's essence and passion. what an incredibly representative image of where peoples' priorities lie. money over life, always. so incredibly sad. but this book was amazing. astounding. it blew me away, totally. i wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone and everyone. i want to harness the passion of life. i want to dig the road, drink in life at its purest, and lose myself in the craziness of the world. i don't want to waste away doing what should be done and following the proper procedure. god, i never want to waste away in contentedness. i never want to be comfortably numb. if i'm riddled with pain and sadness my whole life, i'd rather have that then the blind stupor of a structured life. to put it in a cliche, give me liberty or give me death.

this summer, school supplies will not be bought, peanut butter will be eaten out of the can, lettuce will go bad but will still be eaten, moldy bread will be scraped of as much mold as possible and eaten, and things like flour and baking soda will become side dishes at meal time. i'm not exaggerating. ironically, a $9,000 surgery will be performed upon me on august 22. i think i may just change and passion and soul. i don't think any other author has been able to communicate this lust nearly as effectively as kerouac does. it's not written as the AUTHOR observing and writing with wisdom of the fellow man, it's the author living with and as the fellow man, and telling the things he knows. so very very honest it almost hurts. so far my favorite character is old bull lee, the crazy heroin addict living in new orleans in a shack with his wife and kids, a guy who's traveled the world, who knows so much, who holds with wisdom of centuries, and yet lives on the so-called "bottom rung of NEVER could i create something so incredible. that's not even taking into account others, genius minds like orwell and hesse and tolkein and weissel and atwood and all the other greats out there, many of which i've yet to even discover. how could i ever creat something to the caliber of their genius? how could i create something even worth reading, something other people might find even only good, when most people don't even listen to my thoughts, writing everything i have to say off as just the idealistic passions of a kid? how can i make people listen to me when they're so hell bent upon condescension? but do i have things to say? nothing more than i already know...i know lots of things, i've got the wisdom of youth and experiences lots my age have yet to discover, i know only what i've consumed these 18 years, but compared to the greats of the world of word, i'm a miniscule speck. why would anyone want to read what i have to say? i'm only just acquainting myself with life, unclouding my vision from the mundane, a newborn baby opening her eyes to a new world. and yet i feel that if i can't create something beautiful, if i can't project something honest and true into a web of words, if i can't mold the essence of life as i know it into a sculpture of words, i will die and life will be pointless. if i can't channel this passion and create something that others can benefit from in some way, i will have failed in my life attempts. there's so much i want to do, so much i want to communicate, so much i want to write. but if there's no one there to tell me at least i'm doing what i should be doing, no one there to pat me on the back and tell me i'm following my calling, i don't know if my convictions can withstand. i'll feel like an ass writing superfluous fluff, nothing anyone's not already seen. i'm not emily dickenson, i could never be as strong as her and keep my writings secret. i want to be heard, i couldn't stand remaining silent. i know i spend lots of time on adjectives, writing starry-eyed imagery and probably failing to appear competent, but i really can't help it. it truly is my passion...i just wish i could prove it. if i can't create something worthwile with words, the air might as well just cease in its mad circulation through my lungs, my heart should rest and give up its faithful pulse of life to such a mundane being.

simply being blinded by shock. i won't say anything about it just now. i need to steep in the post-book feelings for a while before i can gather my thoughts. i did want to ask one thing though. so, i think we've all heard the theory that the reason snape killed dumbledore is because dumbledore was dying slowly and painfully, and that's what DD was pleading for, and the look of disgust on snape's face was either snape feeling disgusted that such a great wizard was in such a state, or simply a ruse. playing at being on voldemort's side. whatever. i'd like to hear more about this theory, because it doesn't explain how snape could've known that dumbledore would need snape to kill him months before this episode. it doesn't explain the unbreakable vow. it doesn't explain much of anything...it's kind of a stab in the dark, blind hope that snape isn't that bad. and what the hell is snape going to do now? i mean, if he was doing dumbledore a favor in killing him, how the hell does he expect anyone to believe that? how could he think he'd still be accepted by the order of the phoenix without them killing him the moment they see him? this whole theory is faulty, i just don't see how it could possibly work. and didn't jkr state in the interview with the leaky cauldron and mugglenet that it was hard to make snape do what he did, but that he's indeed a bad guy? i dunno, i'll have to look that part over again, but i seem to remember, when emerson asked her about snape, her shaking her head and confirming that dumbledore was wrong about him. but yeah. that's all i wanted to know. oh yeah--does anyone have theories about RAB? aside from regulus black? i'm kind of leaning toward a character not yet introduced. i'd like people who've read HBP to comment on this entry and give specific reasonings for likes/dislikes, also. and general comments. i haven't discussed the book with anyone, i think we've all been way shocked. anyways, yeah. got stuff from the financial aid office about applying for a stafford loan. so i spent all afternoon online taking this goddamn test that they make you take for some lame reason, and i'm not even finished. i finished the test, but now i've got to do another load of shit before i can even apply for the loan. this is ridiculous. mom's getting a run around about the stock she's trying to close out as well. turns out she has to do about three million things just to prove that she owns the stock, then open an account at some business, then transfer everything there, and then she can finally touch the fucking loan and go about closing it out, which will probably take a month in itself. this is ridiculous. there's no more money to last us througout the summer. all of my graduation money is gone--to bills or buying a loaf of bread and some canned food to last us through the rest of the summer. there's seriously NO money. i guess i won't be getting anything more for going to college...good thing we've already gotten most of my stuff. i don't know how i'll get books for my classes. i'm certain by now that there won't be money until halfway through september. there's not even enough money for gas. how we're going to have enough to get to and from madison on monday for my pre-op, to and from madison the 22 for my surgery, and to and from milwaukee the 29 so i can move in is absolutely beyond me. i did find a check from st. john's for $10 from when i won the art gallery competition in 8th grade though, so they renewed that for me. i guess that will cover one trip to madison. as for the others, everyone's guess is as good as mine. i'm really goddamn sick of being poor. and i'm angry that this has stressed me out. i'm usually very good about never worrying and never stressing myself out (i've dealt with so much stress in my life that i've sworn it and anyone who stresses me out off), but somehow the task of procuring $7,000 out of thin air in 24 days has stressed me out. i'm tired of all of this; i'm tired of banking on miracles to help me survive. it's impossible. it sickens me that i've been tempted to choose a major that will provide me with no passion and no thirst for life, but will rake in a large ammount of money with which to live. i won't do it, i don't think i could ever do that, but i hate the fact that i have to worry about money so much that i'd even think of such a thing. i hate the fact that life as we know it revolves around money--that fully functioning, average human being can't survive without money. seriously. what is money? it is nothing but a symbol of human greed. it serves no purpose in helping a human live, and yet s/he cannot survive without it. the great sickening paradox on which the world turns. i feel like vomitting. i hate all of this. all these bad feelings rose in me today, and what was a beautiful day was ruined by all these negative thoughts dumping from my subconscious into my conscious mind. for the first time in a long time i was consumed in worrying, and i saw again why i hate worrying so much. it's pointless, it results in nothing but bad energy and wasted hours. when people worry, they end up doing things like overeating, oversleeping, and neglecting themselves and everything they care about. and worrying results in nothing. it's a complete waste. far too much of my life has been wasted on worrying. i just want to be carefree and enjoy life and pursue my dreams...alas, this is idealistic wishful thinking, immature and starry-eyed. but i don't want to become old and jaded. i want to enjoy life. i want to do all this without worrying about stupid things like money. this is all stupid and stressful and annoying. there are far more important things in life on which to concentrate my energy and focus. i hate all this. anyways, these bad feelings in me made me think about my summer. i had such plans for it, such hopes. i wanted to shed the gross wasted skin of high school and the former chapter of my life and cleanse who i am. i wanted to figure some things out, spend time out in nature and come into myself a bit more. get a grip on my life. i haven't done a thing. i know college will do this, but i wanted to take advantage of this last summer of freedom and indulge in peace. i forgot that there IS no peace to be had in this house, and it's rarer for me to escape this house than to fricking find a dinosaur fossil in my back yard. i don't know. i just wanted to figure out...something. and i didn't. i knew this summer was going to suck, but not this much.
